UR attention has been called to an error in an editorial in the last issue
of the NEWS-LETTER. In writing of the recently begun course in
Conversational French we intimated that a similar course in German
Conversation would be welcomed by members of this University.
Such an intimation was entirely unnecessary. Although the writer
of the editorial was ignorant of the fact, such a Conversational Class has
been conducted here for years. We are not altogether to be blamed
for this mistake as the NEWS-LETTER printed an editorial on much
the same subject last year without causing comment from the German Department. Be that as it may, we are in fault, and we hasten
to correct our error, and to assure our readers that there is a class in Conversational German.

HIS is probably the dullest season of the collegiate year. Football is
over long ago, and we hear nothing of track and lacrosse beyond the
fact that practice goes forward regularly in the cage. In the social
way there is a little something doing. Hopkins Night, last Tuesday, was very enjoyable. There will be other good shows here soon,
and there is no reason why we should not have another Hopkins Night.
Besides the theatre, there is the Hopkins Dance next Friday night,
a week from today. We can't understand why so little interest
seems to be taken in the Club. Some new subscriptions have been
taken in to be sure, but we want more, and we trust that no one will
be absent, who can possibly arrange to get to the dance.

TWO SONGS.
On the brightest June day
'Mid the roses and flowers,
The heart may be weary;
And long be the hours.
In the depth of the snow,
The heart may be gay—
When spring's in the heart
Then spring's on the way!

I told my love I loved her—
Indeed, I told her so.
How far, far more I loved her
Than I did a year ago—
But with the brightest smiling,
She said "next year you'll say
To some one else the self same words
You've said to me today!"
Said I, "To love you dearer
I'm sure I don't see how—
But I'm very sure—that I'll love you more
This time next year than now!"

THE NEWS-LETTER.

SMUGGLING.
Smuggling is a practice which has, at some
time, made itself evident, to a greater or less
degree, in all the countries of the world. It
is interesting to note that in no nation have
the people generally, ever looked upon smuggling as a question of right or wrong. "The
smuggler was always regarded as a benefactor,
because the people believed that he supplied
better articles at a cheaper rate, than those
on which excise duties were paid. A writer
who was rather partial to smugglers has said,
speaking of the time when this practice was at
its highest point, "To pretend to have any
scruple about buying smuggled goods would
be regarded as a pedantic piece of hypocrisy."
The smuggler himself was often a popular
favorite, and there have been many romantic
stories connected with smugglers and their
trade.
In England smuggling appeared for the first
time, during the thirteenth century, when
counterfeit money began to be introduced
from abroad. This offence was declared a
treason, and legislation on the subject was
active for many years. Smuggling of wine,
spirits, tobacco, and money was practiced continually all around the coast. The Isle of
Man became the centre of so extensive a
smuggling trade that the island was finally
purchased by the British Government at
enormous expense.
English goods were often sent into France
through Belgium. Dogs were trained to carry
valuable packages across the border; it is said
that one dog could easily carry merchandise
worth one hundred and fifty dollars. The
French Government put an end to this method
of smuggling, by offering a reward of three
francs for every dog seized.
Most of the smuggling trade in England
and Scotland was done along the coast.
Revenue officers constantly patrolled the
shores, yet were often deceived by the keener
wits of the more experienced fishermen. In
one sea-port of England, on a rocky coast,
where there were was only one harbor into
which a ship might be run at night, land her
cargo and hurry away before the officers knew
of her approach, there is a story, that a scheme
was once cunningly planned by the smugglers
to kill many of their enemies, the Revenue

officers, and at the same time land their cargo
in safety. The report was spread so as to
come to the officers' ears, that a cargo was to
be landed in "The Cove" on a certain night.
The Revenue officers concealed a party of men
near the inlet, and then put out to sea in their
vessel, determined to seize the smugglers'
ship in the act of running a cargo.
The approach to the harbor was by a narrow channel; and, if a cargo was to be landed
on a dark night, the smugglers' friends on
shore lighted beacons on either side of the
small bay, to act as guides for the vessel about
to "run the cargo." This the officers on
board the Revenue cutter knew and, having
caught sight of the lights on the smugglers'
ship, gave chase. The smuggler easily held
her own, and when nearing the rocky coast,
where the beacons were plainly visible, suddenly extinguished her lights. The Revenue
officers, supposing that the smuggler was
making for the harbor, followed in quick pursuit, using the beacons on either side of the
channel, as their guide. Suddenly the crew
heard the roar of breakers, and made every
effort to regain the open sea. It was useless,
however, and the vessel was wrecked, the
whole of the crew being drowned, excepting
only two or three men. It was afterwards
learned that the smugglers, knowing that the
beacons had been falsely placed on a high
cliff, and not on either side of the bay, had
turned sharply to one side when they extinguished their lights, and had avoided the
destruction to which they knew the Government vessel was doomed. Afterwards the
party of officers on shore was driven away by
the smugglers, the cargo being safely landed
later on in the night.
The fishermen engaged in this perilous
trade were usually of the roughest sort, and it
is said that, if a vessel was wrecked, these
people would often refuse to give any aid to
the sufferers, considering the shipwreck as a
piece of good 'fortune, and the vessel and its
cargo as their lawful prize.
In Scotland the officials whose duty it was
to collect the inland taxes on home products,
were called "excisemen" and they were also
supposed to prevent the smuggling of contraband goods into the country. Robert Burns
was at one time an "excisemen" and proved

THE NEWS-LETTER.

himself an excellent officer. On one occasion
he placed himself at the head of a troop of
dragoons, crossed the Solway, was the first to
board a smuggling brig, captured it, and had
the vessel sold at Dumfries.
In India opium has been smuggled far more
than any other article. In this case, the
smugglers do not attempt to introduce the
opium by importing it from other countries,
but raise it in the inland districts, and try to
smuggle it into the large towns, where, if
successful, they may obtain very high prices.
No one is allowed to raise opium without a
costly permit from the Government, and there
are so many Government inspectors continually
on the watch for this trade that smugglers
,find it difficult to obtain the opium. It seems
that opium has a very peculiar smell which is
easily detected by any one familiar with it.
Farmers have been discovered on railway
trains carrying bags apparently full of onions,
but even the odor of the onions was not strong
enough to draw entirely the opium concealed
in the centre of the bags.
A case of smuggling opium abroad from the
United States was discovered in a somewhat
unusual way. A milkman who carried the
milk on board of out-going steamers was frequently noticed talking to a convicted smuggler. This aroused the suspicions of a
Government inspector, who carelessly jolted
the milkman as he was carrying a can on board
of a vessel about to sail, knocking the can to
the pavement. The inspector learned from
the sound that the can was not hollow, but
solid. He immediately cabled to the ship's
destination, and the inspectors there discovered
that many of the niilk-cans were filled with
opium.
- At the present time the duty on most
imported articles has been lessened until smuggling is confined chiefly to tobacco, precious
stones, gloves and laces.
Jewels are smuggled into this country in
several ways. It does not seem difficult to
carry uncut diamonds in one's pockets, conceal them in the hair, or put them in the heel
of a shoe, but it is found that persons doing
this cannot avoid giving suspicion and being
detected.
Laces are sometimes smuggled by being
placed in the false bottom of a trunk. These

5

false bottoms are not usually more than one
inch in thickness, and cannot be noticed from
the outside except after very close examination.
Gloves has been hidden in the sleeves of a
coat, or sent in letters by mail, and in one
instance a large can of gloves was found in
the middle of a barrel of pitch.
Perhaps the most ingenious plans are used
in smuggling cigars and tobacco. The panelling in officers' cabins has sometimes been
removed, the space being filled with cigars,
brandy, or rum. About twenty bales of
Sumatra tobacco were recently discovered,
hidden under the coal in the bunkers of a
steamship. If any of the officers or crew is
caught in the act of smuggling, the articles
are not only confiscated, but a heavy fine is
also imposed. If the crew of a vessel can be
bribed, however, packages may be lowered
overboard into a waiting launch, usually very
long and painted black, so as not to be
noticeable at night. On one occasion the
authorities were notified that a large amount
of cigars was to be smuggled, and an extra
number of men was detailed to make sure that
the attempt would not be successful.
A rubber bag containing five thousand
cigars was lowered overboard at night from
a vessel in the harbor, caught by a row-boat,
towed to the dock, and landed without attracting attention. The sailor who landed the
cigars was walking up the dock, carrying the
large bundle under his arm, when he was
arrested by a city policeman as a suspicious
character. The fraud was soon discovered by
the city authorities and the Government inspectors who were still watching for the smugglers, were informed to their great chagrin,
that the prey had already been captured.
A peculiar manner of smuggling diamonds
is said to have been used at one time, as follows. The Government was notified that a
party consisting of a man, his wife, a baby,
and its nurse would attempt to import several
very valuable uncut diamonds without paying
the duty. The four were carefully watched
by detectives, but nothing suspicious could be
found. Their baggage was inspected at the
pier, and the persons themselves were very
closely examined, but without success. Just
as they were turning to leave the pier, how-

THE NEWS-LETTER.

ever, the baby dropped its rattle to the floor.
The father's eye lighted upon it, and he
eagerly sprang after the toy, but did not reach
it until the rattle had been smashed to pieces
on the dock, a handful of diamonds rolling
out on the pavement. This ingenious method
of smuggling may often have been used before
successful, and shows what clever schemes
smugglers have learned to adopt.
Smuggling, however, is rapidly becoming
less frequent and, while there will probably be
some smuggling as long as duties are imposed,
the revenue which is lost in this way has
decreased until, at the present time, the loss
is not great enough to be of any serious
importance.

A BALLAD OF LOVE AND DUTY.
The Knight rode out, all armed for war,
His helm and his shield were shining bright,
A blade of proven steel he bore,
And his eyes were aflame with the battlelight.
"The Dragon's claws are sharp and strong,
And life is sweet and death is long,
But I lift my voice in a battle-song
And I set my face to the fight."
His Lady hid her bitter fears,
(For she saw the warrior's heart was
light);
She smiled amid her gentle tears
As she prayed God speed her parting
Knight.
("But what if the prayer is vain I pray;
If death shall take the field today?)
Thy duty calls thee to the fray,
Go forth, dear Love, and fight."

The Knight rode back with the Dragon's
head,
(His lance and his helm no longer bright).
"I feared, I feared," the Lady said,
"But love must yield and I sent my
Knight
When duty's call to battle rang,
And none but I could know the pang,
For I feared the death of the Dragon's fang;
But I sent him forth to fight."

THE PERCY TURNBULL MEMORIAL
LECTURES ON POETRY.

1892. Professor RICHARD C. JEBB, LL.D., D. C. L.,
of the University of Cambridge—"The Growth and
Influence of Classical Greek Poetry."

FIFTEENTH COURSE-1908.

1893. Professor ROBERT Y. TYRRELL, LL.D., Litt.
D., of Trinity College, Dublin—"The Growth and
Influence of Latin Poetry."

PROFESSOR A. V. WILLIAMS'JACKSON
ON THE POETRY OF PERSIA.

For the purpose of commemorating the name
of their son, Percy Graeme Turnbull, who
died in 1887, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Turnbull, of Baltimore, made provision, in 1889,
for lectures on poetry to be given before this
University.
In accordance with the terms of the gift, a
course of lectures by some one who has gained
distinction as a writer or critical student of
poetry may be expected annually.
The Trustees hereby announce that the
fifteenth course of lectures on this foundation
will be given by A. V. Williams Jackson,
Ph. D., LL. D., Professor of Judo-Iranian
Languages in Columbia University. The general subject will be The Poetry of Persia.
The lectures will be given in McCoy Hall, at
5 o'clock, beginning Tuesday, January 28,
1908.
The lectures will begin punctually and will
close within the hour. The door will be closed
when the lecturer rises.
Cards of admission will be required. They
may be obtained on application, by mail, to
the Registrar, and their issue will be limited.

THE POETRY OF PERSIA.
Tuesday, January 28th—The Beginnings of
Persian Poetry.
Wednesday, January 29th—Firdusi and the
great Persian Epic.
Thursday, January 30th —The Homes of the
Persian Poets.
Tuesday, February 4th — T he Romantic
Poetry of Persia.
Wednesday, February 5th—Omar Khayyam
and His Predecessors.
Thursday, February 6th—Persian Mystic
Poetry.
Tuesday, February llth—Saadi and Hafiz,
the renowned Poets of Shiraz.

THE TURNBULL LECTURER.
Abraham Valentine Williams Jackson, A.
M., Ph.D., L.H.D., 14.14.D., was born in
New York in 1862. He graduated from
Columbia in 1883, and after several years of
graduate study, spent two years in Germany.
On his return, he was appointed an associate
in English literature which position he occupied
until 1895, when he accepted the chair of
Judo-Iranian languages. This position he
holds today. He has travelled in India,
Persia, and Central Asia, mainly for the purposes of research. He has published several
volumes relating to Persia, and other subjects
in his special line of research, and has contributed largely to various learned periodicals.
During the course of his career he has done a
good deal of public lecturing and was, we
believe, invited to give the Turnbull Lecturers
several winters ago, but at that time found it
impossible to do so.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE ALUMNUS' STORY.
"Yes," said the returned Alumnus, as we
seated ourselves in a retired corner of the
library, "this is how it all happened. One
morning in October in my first post-graduate
year they found the photograph of the last
year's senior class—my class—broken from its
frame, torn up, and strewn over the floor
around the place where it had been hanging,
in McCoy Hall, second floor, right there by
the Dean's room, you know. I had left for
Europe three days after the photograph had
been taken in June, and had consequently not
seen the picture until the Fall.
"Well, they talked about the destruction of
the photograph for a week or two, but no one
ever arrived at any conclusion because there
was only one man who knew how the picture
had been damaged, and that was myself.
'Since my earliest days I had had an almost
uncontrollable dislike of being on the left side
of a group'of people. At home my place had
always been at the right side of the diningtable; and in my football days I always insisted upon playing in the right side of the
line. It is impossible to describe to you the
curious feeling of dread that used to possess
me whenever I found myself misplaced in a
group; I might compare it to homesickness in
its worst form—a feeling that one must do
something or die. As I look back upon it I
cannot think it simply childish, for as the rest
of my story will show, it contained very
serious possibilities.
"When the photograph was taken I placed
myself in the right side of the group and
thought no more about it. But when in October I saw the print for the first time, I perceived that as the photograph was taken from
the front of the group I was represented on
the left side of Ike picture! Then I realized
for the first time the strange fact that this
mental antipathy extended not only to my
physical being but even to the pictorial representation of myself. I struggled with all my
will-power against the nervous terror that

9

began to come over me, but in vain. It increased hourly until from a mere incidental
idea it became a dominant force, and until- in
a few days I was suffering more acutely than
any physical pain could cause.
"Perhaps you have observed that curious
state between waking and dreaming when the
imagination runs riot and the brain, while
perfectly conscious, cannot c on trol the
thoughts. Under the influence of such a
state I have at times imagined myself dizzily
spinning around, top-fashion, and although
quite aware that it was only fancy I have been
quite unable to compel the imagination to
cease its working. Such a state lasts only a
few minutes, till sleep or perfect consciousness puts an end to it; at the time of which I
am telling you I was in a similar condition,
which lasted for days. I could not overcome
what I knew to be only a delusion, an interesting case for the psychopathologist. I attended
my classes, and performed my daily duties
regularly, but the things of reality were but a
dream, while the dream had all the aspects of
reality.
"One day about six o'clock, as I came down
the corridor from the Seminary, where I had
been doing some late work, my eyes fell upon
the picture. The wild feeling of mental and
physical distortion came over me with
redoubled force. How can I make it clear to
you? It seemed as if I should have been by
all rule and right in the other side of the
group; that a force greater than myself had
dragged me away from my place, straining
every nerve and fibre in my body. I imagine
that my thoughts were like the thoughts of a
man who awakes from a trance and realizes
in one brief instant of mental clearness that
they have nailed the coffin-lid down and cast
the clods upon him.
"And there was the frame, directly within
my reach—
`With the rattle of broken glass I came to
my senses. I left the hall in a state of considerable excitement, and have never had a
return of this astonishing malady.—I'm
awfully obliged to you, for taking me over
the old place again; it certainly has changed
since I first cribbed my Horace and mixed
poison in the chemical lab. So long."
I wonder if it all did happen?

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE TRACK TEAM.
The track season is well under way now,
and judging from the work of the men who
are out for the team, the present season should
be a most successful one. Our distance men,
Breyer and Brenton, have already scored a
triumph for Hopkins, when they won first and
second places in the open cross-country run
held by Georgetown, on January 1. This
victory of our distance runners was a notable
one, for they were in competition with some
of the best distance men in the East; in fact
it was a Yale man who won third place.
There is one thing noticed among the candidates for the track team, and that is the
small number of Freshmen who are coming
out for practice. Often there are one or two,
and on rare occasions three or four Freshmen
practicing in the cage on track afternoons.
The question, "What is the matter with the
Freshmen?" is heard on all sides. Well, what
is the matter with the Freshmen? They have
some very good material in their class, which
could be developed if the men worked. Freshmen, you simply must come out and work, if
you have the interest of the 'Varsity at heart.
Manager Wylie announces two track events
of great interest, which will be held sometime
during February. The first of these is a track
and field meet between the Seniors and Juinors. Last year the present Juniors defeated
the Seniors by a scant margin. Judging from
this the meet will be a close one. The second
event is an open cross-country run to be held
at Homewood. The prizes for this event will
probably be a cup for the winner and medals
for second and third places.
Our men expect to make a good showing at
the George Washington University meet,
which will be held in Washington this Saturday. Our relay team is in good condition and
if all goes well we should win the 2-mile relay
with George Washington University and the
University of Virginia. Those who are entered
in the events are as follows:
50-yard Dash (novice)—Wallace, Schneeberger and Wylie.
50-yard Dash (open handicap) —Bailey,
Stollenwerck, Burgan and Wallace.
440-yard Run (open handicap)—Bailey and
Stollenwerck.

600-yard Run (open novice)—Schneeberger
and Wallace.
Mile Run—Breyer and Griffith.
Pole Vault—Bridgeman.
High Jump—Schneeberger and Burgan.
2-mile Relay—Breyer, Brenton, Burgan,
Tredway, Griffith, Stewart and Wallace.

JUNIORS, 49—FRESHMEN, 23.
The second annual meet of the Juniors and
Freshmen track teams was held last Saturday
with great success. There was a fine crowd,
in fact every inch of available space in the
cage was occupied. Most of the events were
closely contested, but. it was unfortunate that
the Freshmen did not show better organization, and have more men out for the events.
Captain Bailey, of the Junior team organized
his men in a highly efficient manner, and it
was largely due to his efforts that the Juniors
won by such a great margin.
Two surprises were sprung, in the excellent
work of Walters, '09 and Burgan, '11. The
former, who entered the University this
year, having been a student at Yale last year,
succeeded in dJeating Michael, who has
represented the 'Varsity in the shot-put the
last two seasons. The second surprise was
the fine work of Burgan. He won the high
jump handily, and showed excellent form in
the half mile run, which he won easily. If
these two men keep up their good work, they
will undoubtedly be valuable additions to the
track team.
One of the prettiest races was the 30-yard
dash, in which Stollenwerck was defeated by
Bailey. Coach West was pleased by the work
done by most of the men, and he said that if
only the fellows, especially the Freshmen,
would come out for the practices, there would
be no doubt as to the success of the track
team this year. The summaries of events.
30-yard Dash—First, Bailey (J.); second,
Stollenwerck (F..); third, Bevan (J.).

Wallace (J.); third, Wolfe (F.).
Half-Mile Run—First, Burgan (F.); second,
Wallace (J.); third, Makle (F.).
Mile Run—First, Gutman (J.); second,
Russell (J.); third, Musser (F.).
High Jump—First, Burgan (F.); second,

THE NEW BOOK SHELF.

The Cambridge History of English Literature, edited by A. W. Ward and A. R
Waller. Vol. I. From the Beginnings to the
Cycles of Romance.
To the general reader this initial volume is
interesting, perhaps, more for what it promises
in subsequent volumes than for what it actually contains. But for many of us, even if we
are not versed in Anglo-Saxon and Middle
English, there is much that is most interesting in the period which is treated of in this
volume. First in interest is the whole cycle
of Arthurian Romance and all the lesser and
originally independent legends which graduually became incorporated with the stories of
Arthur. This body of legends has exerted
more influence on our literature than any
other one source of influence. Chaucer,
Spencer, Milton, Tennyson, Swinburne, all
have been fascinated by the charm of the
stories. The chapters on "The Arthurian
Legend," on "Metrical Romances," and on
"Sir Gawayne and the Green Knight" are
the most interesting. Chapter XIX,"Changes
in the Language to the Days of Chaucer," is
instructive and clearly and:concisely expressed.
It is a pity that (p. 440) there are two misprints of old English alphabetical characters—
which, as the types are beyond the resources
of our printers, we can only call attention to.
It has become commonplace to remark that
this first volume is a history of English Literature before England had any literature. This

is, of course, absurd. Because every man
that reads the Sunday paper is not interested
in the Mabinogion, that does not make the
Mabinogion the less valuable.
Since the publication of the first volume of
the Cambridge Modern History, five years
ago, there has been a good deal of criticism as
to the merits of histories written on the monograph plan. Of course a certain unity of
treatment is .lost thereby and occasionally
statements are needlessly repeated by the
writers of different chapters. These are disadvantages, but they are lost sight of when
we consider that each chapter is written by a
man who is an acknowledged authority on
that particular portion of history.
Altogether the volume is most satisfactory,
and if we find the treatment of this remote
time of interest, how great will be our delight
when the undertaking has progressed as far
as the two volumes promised us_ on "The
Elizabethan and Jacobean Drama."

Conversational French we intimated that a similar course in German
Conversation would be welcomed by members of this University.
Such an intimation was entirely unnecessary. Although the writer
of the editorial was ignorant of the fact, such a Conversational Class has
been conducted here for years. We are not altogether to be blamed
for this mistake as the NEWS-LETTER printed an editorial on much
the same subject last year without causing comment from the German Department. Be that as it may, we are in fault, and we hasten
to correct our error, and to assure our readers that there is a class in Conversational German.

HIS is probably the dullest season of the collegiate year. Football is
over long ago, and we hear nothing of track and lacrosse beyond the
fact that practice goes forward regularly in the cage. In the social

and there is no reason why we should not have another Hopkins Night.
Besides the theatre, there is the Hopkins Dance next Friday night,

seems to be taken in the Club. Some new subscriptions have been
taken in to be sure, but we want more, and we trust that no one will
be absent, who can possibly arrange to get to the dance.

TWO SONGS.
On the brightest June day
'Mid the roses and flowers,
The heart may be weary;
And long be the hours.
In the depth of the snow,
The heart may be gay—
When spring's in the heart
Then spring's on the way!

I told my love I loved her—
Indeed, I told her so.
How far, far more I loved her
Than I did a year ago—
But with the brightest smiling,
She said "next year you'll say
To some one else the self same words
You've said to me today!"
Said I, "To love you dearer
I'm sure I don't see how—
But I'm very sure—that I'll love you more
This time next year than now!"

THE NEWS-LETTER.
=7

SMUGGLING.
Smuggling is a practice which has, at some
time, made itself evident, to a greater or less
degree, in all the countries of the world. It
is interesting to note that in no nation have
the people generally, ever looked upon smuggling as a question of right or wrong. "The
smuggler was always regarded as a benefactor,
because the people believed that he supplied
better articles at a cheaper rate, than those
on which excise duties were paid. A writer
who was rather partial to smugglers has said,
speaking of the time when this practice was at
its highest point, "To pretend to have any
scruple about buying smuggled goods would
be regarded as a pedantic piece of hypocrisy."
The smuggler himself was often a popular
favorite, and there have been many romantic
stories connected with smugglers and their
trade.
In England smuggling appeared for the first
time, during the thirteenth century, when
counterfeit money began to be introduced
from abroad. This offence was declared a
treason, and legislation on the subject was
active for many years. Smuggling of wine,
spirits, tobacco, and money was practiced continually all around the coast. The Isle of
Man became the centre of so extensive a
smuggling trade that the island was finally
purchased by the British Government at
enormous expense.
English goods were often sent into France
through Belgium. Dogs were trained to carry
valuable packages across the border; it is said
that one dog could easily carry merchandise
worth one hundred and fifty dollars. The
French Government put an end to this method
of smuggling, by offering a reward of three
francs for every dog seized.
Most of the smuggling trade in England
and Scotland was done along the coast.
Revenue officers constantly patrolled the
shores, yet were often deceived by the keener
wits of the more experienced fishermen. In
one sea-port of England, on a rocky coast,
where there were was only one harbor into
which a ship might be run at night, land her
cargo and hurry away before the officers knew
of her approach, there is a story, that a scheme
was once cunningly planned by the smugglers
to kill many of their enemies, the Revenue

officers, and at the same time land their cargo
in safety. The report was spread so as to
come to the officers' ears, that a cargo was to
be landed in "The Cove" on a certain night.
The Revenue officers concealed a party of men
near the inlet, and then put out to sea in their
vessel, determined to seize the smugglers'
ship in the act of running a cargo.
The approach to the harbor was by a narrow channel; and, if a cargo was to be landed
on a dark night, the smugglers' friends on
shore lighted beacons on either side of the
small bay, to act as guides for the vessel about
to "run the cargo." This the officers on
board the Revenue cutter knew and, having
caught sight of the lights on the smugglers'
ship, gave chase. The smuggler easily held
her own, and when nearing the rocky coast,
where the beacons were plainly visible, suddenly extinguished her lights. The Revenue
officers, supposing that the smuggler was
making for the harbor, followed in quick pursuit, using the beacons on either side of the
channel, as their guide. Suddenly the crew
heard the roar of breakers, and made every
effort to regain the open sea. It was useless,
however, and the vessel was wrecked, the
whole of the crew being drowned, excepting
only two or three men. It was afterwards
learned that the smugglers, knowing that the
beacons had been falsely placed on a high
cliff, and not on either side of the bay, had
turned sharply to one side when they extinguished their lights, and had avoided the
destruction to which they knew the Government vessel was doomed. Afterwards the
party of officers on shore was driven away by
the smugglers, the cargo being safely landed
later on in the night.
The fishermen engaged in this perilous
trade were usually of the roughest sort, and it
is said that, if a vessel was wrecked, these
people would often refuse to give any aid to
the sufferers, considering the shipwreck as a
piece of good 'fortune, and the vessel and its
cargo as their lawful prize.
In Scotland the officials whose duty it was
to collect the inland taxes on home products,
were called "excisemen" and they were also
supposed to prevent the smuggling of contraband goods into the country. Robert Burns
was at one time an "excisemen" and proved

THE NEWS-LETTER.

himself an excellent officer. On one occasion
he placed himself at the head of a troop of
dragoons, crossed the Solway, was the first to
board a smuggling brig, captured it, and had
the vessel sold at Dumfries.
In India opium has been smuggled far more
than any other article. In this case, the
smugglers do not attempt to introduce the
opium by importing it from other countries,
but raise it in the inland districts, and try to
smuggle it into the large towns, where, if
successful, they may obtain very high prices.
No one is allowed to raise opium without a
costly permit from the Government, and there
are so many Government inspectors continually
on the watch for this trade that smugglers
,find it difficult to obtain the opium. It seems
that opium has a very peculiar smell which is
easily detected by any one familiar with it.
Farmers have been discovered on railway
trains carrying bags apparently full of onions,
but even the odor of the onions was not strong
enough to draw entirely the opium concealed
in the centre of the bags.
A case of smuggling opium abroad from the
United States was discovered in a somewhat
unusual way. A milkman who carried the
milk on board of out-going steamers was frequently noticed talking to a convicted smuggler. This aroused the suspicions of a
Government inspector, who carelessly jolted
the milkman as he was carrying a can on board
of a vessel about to sail, knocking the can to
the pavement. The inspector learned from
the sound that the can was not hollow, but
solid. He immediately cabled to the ship's
destination, and the inspectors there discovered
that many of the niilk-cans were filled with
opium.
- At the present time the duty on most
imported articles has been lessened until smuggling is confined chiefly to tobacco, precious
stones, gloves and laces.
Jewels are smuggled into this country in
several ways. It does not seem difficult to
carry uncut diamonds in one's pockets, conceal them in the hair, or put them in the heel
of a shoe, but it is found that persons doing
this cannot avoid giving suspicion and being
detected.
Laces are sometimes smuggled by being
placed in the false bottom of a trunk. These

5

false bottoms are not usually more than one
inch in thickness, and cannot be noticed from
the outside except after very close examination.
Gloves has been hidden in the sleeves of a
coat, or sent in letters by mail, and in one
instance a large can of gloves was found in
the middle of a barrel of pitch.
Perhaps the most ingenious plans are used
in smuggling cigars and tobacco. The panelling in officers' cabins has sometimes been
removed, the space being filled with cigars,
brandy, or rum. About twenty bales of
Sumatra tobacco were recently discovered,
hidden under the coal in the bunkers of a
steamship. If any of the officers or crew is
caught in the act of smuggling, the articles
are not only confiscated, but a heavy fine is
also imposed. If the crew of a vessel can be
bribed, however, packages may be lowered
overboard into a waiting launch, usually very
long and painted black, so as not to be
noticeable at night. On one occasion the
authorities were notified that a large amount
of cigars was to be smuggled, and an extra
number of men was detailed to make sure that
the attempt would not be successful.
A rubber bag containing five thousand
cigars was lowered overboard at night from
a vessel in the harbor, caught by a row-boat,
towed to the dock, and landed without attracting attention. The sailor who landed the
cigars was walking up the dock, carrying the
large bundle under his arm, when he was
arrested by a city policeman as a suspicious
character. The fraud was soon discovered by
the city authorities and the Government inspectors who were still watching for the smugglers, were informed to their great chagrin,
that the prey had already been captured.
A peculiar manner of smuggling diamonds
is said to have been used at one time, as follows. The Government was notified that a
party consisting of a man, his wife, a baby,
and its nurse would attempt to import several
very valuable uncut diamonds without paying
the duty. The four were carefully watched
by detectives, but nothing suspicious could be
found. Their baggage was inspected at the
pier, and the persons themselves were very
closely examined, but without success. Just
as they were turning to leave the pier, how-

THE NEWS-LETTER.

ever, the baby dropped its rattle to the floor.
The father's eye lighted upon it, and he
eagerly sprang after the toy, but did not reach
it until the rattle had been smashed to pieces
on the dock, a handful of diamonds rolling
out on the pavement. This ingenious method
of smuggling may often have been used before
successful, and shows what clever schemes
smugglers have learned to adopt.
Smuggling, however, is rapidly becoming
less frequent and, while there will probably be
some smuggling as long as duties are imposed,
the revenue which is lost in this way has
decreased until, at the present time, the loss
is not great enough to be of any serious
importance.

A BALLAD OF LOVE AND DUTY.
The Knight rode out, all armed for war,
His helm and his shield were shining bright,
A blade of proven steel he bore,
And his eyes were aflame with the battlelight.
"The Dragon's claws are sharp and strong,
And life is sweet and death is long,
But I lift my voice in a battle-song
And I set my face to the fight."
His Lady hid her bitter fears,
(For she saw the warrior's heart was
light);
She smiled amid her gentle tears
As she prayed God speed her parting
Knight.
("But what if the prayer is vain I pray;
If death shall take the field today?)
Thy duty calls thee to the fray,
Go forth, dear Love, and fight."

The Knight rode back with the Dragon's
head,
(His lance and his helm no longer bright).
"I feared, I feared," the Lady said,
"But love must yield and I sent my
Knight
When duty's call to battle rang,
And none but I could know the pang,
For I feared the death of the Dragon's fang;
But I sent him forth to fight."

THE PERCY TURNBULL MEMORIAL
LECTURES ON POETRY.

1892. Professor RICHARD C. JEBB, LL.D., D. C. L.,
of the University of Cambridge—"The Growth and
Influence of Classical Greek Poetry."

FIFTEENTH COURSE-1908.

1893. Professor ROBERT Y. TYRRELL, LL.D., Litt.
D., of Trinity College, Dublin—"The Growth and
Influence of Latin Poetry."

PROFESSOR A. V. WILLIAMS'JACKSON
ON THE POETRY OF PERSIA.

For the purpose of commemorating the name
of their son, Percy Graeme Turnbull, who
died in 1887, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Turnbull, of Baltimore, made provision, in 1889,
for lectures on poetry to be given before this
University.
In accordance with the terms of the gift, a
course of lectures by some one who has gained
distinction as a writer or critical student of
poetry may be expected annually.
The Trustees hereby announce that the
fifteenth course of lectures on this foundation
will be given by A. V. Williams Jackson,
Ph. D., LL. D., Professor of Judo-Iranian
Languages in Columbia University. The general subject will be The Poetry of Persia.
The lectures will be given in McCoy Hall, at
5 o'clock, beginning Tuesday, January 28,
1908.
The lectures will begin punctually and will
close within the hour. The door will be closed
when the lecturer rises.
Cards of admission will be required. They
may be obtained on application, by mail, to
the Registrar, and their issue will be limited.

THE POETRY OF PERSIA.
Tuesday, January 28th—The Beginnings of
Persian Poetry.
Wednesday, January 29th—Firdusi and the
great Persian Epic.
Thursday, January 30th —The Homes of the
Persian Poets.
Tuesday, February 4th — T he Romantic
Poetry of Persia.
Wednesday, February 5th—Omar Khayyam
and His Predecessors.
Thursday, February 6th—Persian Mystic
Poetry.
Tuesday, February llth—Saadi and Hafiz,
the renowned Poets of Shiraz.

LECTURERS ON THIS, FOUNDATION.
1891. EDMUND C. STEDMAN, LL.D., of New York—
"The Nature and Elements of Poetry."

D. C. L., of Harvard University—"Dante."

Itree Church College, Glasgow—"Hebrew Poetry."
1897. M. FERDINAND BRUNETIERE, Editor of the
"Revue des Deux Mondes"—"French Poetry."
1898. Professor CHARLES R. LANMAN, Ph.D., of
Harvard University—"Poetry of India."
1900. Professor CHARLES H. HERVORD, Litt. D., of
the University College of Wales—"English Poetry."

Editor of ''The Outlook."—"Poetry in America."

Poetry."

THE TURNBULL LECTURER.
Abraham Valentine Williams Jackson, A.
M., Ph.D., L.H.D., 14.14.D., was born in
New York in 1862. He graduated from
Columbia in 1883, and after several years of
graduate study, spent two years in Germany.
On his return, he was appointed an associate
in English literature which position he occupied
until 1895, when he accepted the chair of
Judo-Iranian languages. This position he
holds today. He has travelled in India,
Persia, and Central Asia, mainly for the purposes of research. He has published several
volumes relating to Persia, and other subjects
in his special line of research, and has contributed largely to various learned periodicals.
During the course of his career he has done a
good deal of public lecturing and was, we
believe, invited to give the Turnbull Lecturers
several winters ago, but at that time found it
impossible to do so.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE ALUMNUS' STORY.
"Yes," said the returned Alumnus, as we
seated ourselves in a retired corner of the
library, "this is how it all happened. One
morning in October in my first post-graduate
year they found the photograph of the last
year's senior class—my class—broken from its
frame, torn up, and strewn over the floor
around the place where it had been hanging,
in McCoy Hall, second floor, right there by
the Dean's room, you know. I had left for
Europe three days after the photograph had
been taken in June, and had consequently not
seen the picture until the Fall.
"Well, they talked about the destruction of
the photograph for a week or two, but no one
ever arrived at any conclusion because there
was only one man who knew how the picture
had been damaged, and that was myself.
'Since my earliest days I had had an almost
uncontrollable dislike of being on the left side
of a group'of people. At home my place had
always been at the right side of the diningtable; and in my football days I always insisted upon playing in the right side of the
line. It is impossible to describe to you the
curious feeling of dread that used to possess
me whenever I found myself misplaced in a
group; I might compare it to homesickness in
its worst form—a feeling that one must do
something or die. As I look back upon it I
cannot think it simply childish, for as the rest
of my story will show, it contained very
serious possibilities.
"When the photograph was taken I placed
myself in the right side of the group and
thought no more about it. But when in October I saw the print for the first time, I perceived that as the photograph was taken from
the front of the group I was represented on
the left side of Ike picture! Then I realized
for the first time the strange fact that this
mental antipathy extended not only to my
physical being but even to the pictorial representation of myself. I struggled with all my
will-power against the nervous terror that

9

began to come over me, but in vain. It increased hourly until from a mere incidental
idea it became a dominant force, and until- in
a few days I was suffering more acutely than
any physical pain could cause.
"Perhaps you have observed that curious
state between waking and dreaming when the
imagination runs riot and the brain, while
perfectly conscious, cannot c on trol the
thoughts. Under the influence of such a
state I have at times imagined myself dizzily
spinning around, top-fashion, and although
quite aware that it was only fancy I have been
quite unable to compel the imagination to
cease its working. Such a state lasts only a
few minutes, till sleep or perfect consciousness puts an end to it; at the time of which I
am telling you I was in a similar condition,
which lasted for days. I could not overcome
what I knew to be only a delusion, an interesting case for the psychopathologist. I attended
my classes, and performed my daily duties
regularly, but the things of reality were but a
dream, while the dream had all the aspects of
reality.
"One day about six o'clock, as I came down
the corridor from the Seminary, where I had
been doing some late work, my eyes fell upon
the picture. The wild feeling of mental and
physical distortion came over me with
redoubled force. How can I make it clear to
you? It seemed as if I should have been by
all rule and right in the other side of the
group; that a force greater than myself had
dragged me away from my place, straining
every nerve and fibre in my body. I imagine
that my thoughts were like the thoughts of a
man who awakes from a trance and realizes
in one brief instant of mental clearness that
they have nailed the coffin-lid down and cast
the clods upon him.
"And there was the frame, directly within
my reach—
`With the rattle of broken glass I came to
my senses. I left the hall in a state of considerable excitement, and have never had a
return of this astonishing malady.—I'm
awfully obliged to you, for taking me over
the old place again; it certainly has changed
since I first cribbed my Horace and mixed
poison in the chemical lab. So long."
I wonder if it all did happen?

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE TRACK TEAM.
The track season is well under way now,
and judging from the work of the men who
are out for the team, the present season should
be a most successful one. Our distance men,
Breyer and Brenton, have already scored a
triumph for Hopkins, when they won first and
second places in the open cross-country run
held by Georgetown, on January 1. This
victory of our distance runners was a notable
one, for they were in competition with some
of the best distance men in the East; in fact
it was a Yale man who won third place.
There is one thing noticed among the candidates for the track team, and that is the
small number of Freshmen who are coming
out for practice. Often there are one or two,
and on rare occasions three or four Freshmen
practicing in the cage on track afternoons.
The question, "What is the matter with the
Freshmen?" is heard on all sides. Well, what
is the matter with the Freshmen? They have
some very good material in their class, which
could be developed if the men worked. Freshmen, you simply must come out and work, if
you have the interest of the 'Varsity at heart.
Manager Wylie announces two track events
of great interest, which will be held sometime
during February. The first of these is a track
and field meet between the Seniors and Juinors. Last year the present Juniors defeated
the Seniors by a scant margin. Judging from
this the meet will be a close one. The second
event is an open cross-country run to be held
at Homewood. The prizes for this event will
probably be a cup for the winner and medals
for second and third places.
Our men expect to make a good showing at
the George Washington University meet,
which will be held in Washington this Saturday. Our relay team is in good condition and
if all goes well we should win the 2-mile relay
with George Washington University and the
University of Virginia. Those who are entered
in the events are as follows:
50-yard Dash (novice)—Wallace, Schneeberger and Wylie.
50-yard Dash (open handicap) —Bailey,
Stollenwerck, Burgan and Wallace.
440-yard Run (open handicap)—Bailey and
Stollenwerck.

600-yard Run (open novice)—Schneeberger
and Wallace.
Mile Run—Breyer and Griffith.
Pole Vault—Bridgeman.
High Jump—Schneeberger and Burgan.
2-mile Relay—Breyer, Brenton, Burgan,
Tredway, Griffith, Stewart and Wallace.

JUNIORS, 49—FRESHMEN, 23.
The second annual meet of the Juniors and
Freshmen track teams was held last Saturday
with great success. There was a fine crowd,
in fact every inch of available space in the
cage was occupied. Most of the events were
closely contested, but. it was unfortunate that
the Freshmen did not show better organization, and have more men out for the events.
Captain Bailey, of the Junior team organized
his men in a highly efficient manner, and it
was largely due to his efforts that the Juniors
won by such a great margin.
Two surprises were sprung, in the excellent
work of Walters, '09 and Burgan, '11. The
former, who entered the University this
year, having been a student at Yale last year,
succeeded in dJeating Michael, who has
represented the 'Varsity in the shot-put the
last two seasons. The second surprise was
the fine work of Burgan. He won the high
jump handily, and showed excellent form in
the half mile run, which he won easily. If
these two men keep up their good work, they
will undoubtedly be valuable additions to the
track team.
One of the prettiest races was the 30-yard
dash, in which Stollenwerck was defeated by
Bailey. Coach West was pleased by the work
done by most of the men, and he said that if
only the fellows, especially the Freshmen,
would come out for the practices, there would
be no doubt as to the success of the track
team this year. The summaries of events.
30-yard Dash—First, Bailey (J.); second,
Stollenwerck (F..); third, Bevan (J.).
440-yard Run—First, Bailey (J.); second,
Wallace (J.); third, Wolfe (F.).
Half-Mile Run—First, Burgan (F.); second,
Wallace (J.); third, Makle (F.).
Mile Run—First, Gutman (J.); second,
Russell (J.); third, Musser (F.).
High Jump—First, Burgan (F.); second,

The Cambridge History of English Literature, edited by A. W. Ward and A. R
Waller. Vol. I. From the Beginnings to the
Cycles of Romance.
To the general reader this initial volume is
interesting, perhaps, more for what it promises
in subsequent volumes than for what it actually contains. But for many of us, even if we
are not versed in Anglo-Saxon and Middle
English, there is much that is most interesting in the period which is treated of in this
volume. First in interest is the whole cycle
of Arthurian Romance and all the lesser and
originally independent legends which graduually became incorporated with the stories of
Arthur. This body of legends has exerted
more influence on our literature than any
other one source of influence. Chaucer,
Spencer, Milton, Tennyson, Swinburne, all
have been fascinated by the charm of the
stories. The chapters on "The Arthurian
Legend," on "Metrical Romances," and on
"Sir Gawayne and the Green Knight" are
the most interesting. Chapter XIX,"Changes
in the Language to the Days of Chaucer," is
instructive and clearly and:concisely expressed.
It is a pity that (p. 440) there are two misprints of old English alphabetical characters—
which, as the types are beyond the resources
of our printers, we can only call attention to.
It has become commonplace to remark that
this first volume is a history of English Literature before England had any literature. This

is, of course, absurd. Because every man
that reads the Sunday paper is not interested
in the Mabinogion, that does not make the

Since the publication of the first volume of
the Cambridge Modern History, five years
ago, there has been a good deal of criticism as
to the merits of histories written on the monograph plan. Of course a certain unity of
treatment is .lost thereby and occasionally
statements are needlessly repeated by the
writers of different chapters. These are disadvantages, but they are lost sight of when
we consider that each chapter is written by a
man who is an acknowledged authority on
that particular portion of history.
Altogether the volume is most satisfactory,
and if we find the treatment of this remote
time of interest, how great will be our delight
when the undertaking has progressed as far
as the two volumes promised us_ on "The
